Sammy the snake plant is doing great, eh? That's wonderful!

While both Spider plants and Snake plants are low-maintenance, they have different growth habits and requirements. Spider plants are more delicate and produce more foliage, whereas Snake plants are more robust and focus on producing new leaves.

Given Lola's specific needs, I'd recommend adjusting the fertilization frequency slightly. Since Spider plants are lighter feeders than Snake plants, you can start with a slightly less frequent fertilization schedule.

For Lola, you can try fertilizing every 4-6 weeks during the growing season (spring and summer) with a balanced, water-soluble fertilizer (20-20-20). This will provide her with a steady supply of nutrients without over-fertilizing.

During the dormant season (fall and winter), you can reduce fertilization to every 8-12 weeks. This will help conserve energy and prevent excessive growth during a time when the plant is naturally slower.

Remember to dilute the fertilizer to half the recommended strength to avoid burning Lola's roots. You can always adjust the frequency based on her response and growth rate.

Keep in mind that Spider plants are more sensitive to over-fertilization, so it's better to err on the side of caution. Monitor Lola's growth, and if you notice any signs of nutrient deficiency (like yellowing leaves or stunted growth), you can increase the fertilization frequency slightly.

Sammy the snake plant, on the other hand, can likely continue to thrive with the once-a-month fertilization schedule you've established.

How's that? Are you comfortable with adjusting Lola's fertilization schedule, or do you have any further questions?
